c74object.name: fl.spatial~
c74object.digest: Generates multiplication factors for a set of speakers positioned in 3D
c74object.description: The core underlying algorithm is DBAP (distance-based amplitude panning). Input may use cartesian [x, y, z] or polar [radius, azimuth, elevation] coordinates. 2D operation can be achieved by setting all z or elevation values to zero. Angles may be set using degrees or radians. Missing values at any input are assumed to be zero. The output size is equal to that of the largest input.

entry.name: /angles [enum]
entry.description:
Sets the units used for angles.
[0] - radians[1] - degrees
(default: degrees)

entry.name: /input_coords [enum]
entry.description:
INSTANTIATION ONLYSets the coordinate system used for input.
[0] - polar[1] - cartesian
(default: polar)

entry.name: /speaker_coords [enum]
entry.description:
INSTANTIATION ONLYSets the coordinate system used for speaker positions.
[0] - polar[1] - cartesian
(default: polar)

entry.name: /constrain [enum]
entry.description:
Sets the method for constraining positions outside of the speaker array:
[0] - none - suitable when the input is already within the speaker array (most efficient).[1] - hemisphere - restrict to the upper hemisphere of the sphere described below.[2] - sphere - restrict to the smallest sphere centred at the origin containing all speakers.[3] - hull - restrict to the convex hull of the speaker array (least efficient / always correct.
(default: hull)

entry.name: /speakers [variable length double array]
entry.description:
INSTANTIATION ONLYSets the speaker positions in triples (one triple per speaker). For cartesian coordinates the values are [x, z, y]. For polar coordinates the values are [radius, azimuth, elevation].
(default: 0)

entry.name: /weights [variable length double array]
entry.description:
Sets the speaker weightings (one value per speaker). By default all speakers are weighted equally. Using weighting values allows the emphasis or exclusion of specific speakers.
(default: 1)

entry.name: /rolloff [double]
entry.description:
Sets the rolloff in positive dB for a doubling of distance between source and speakers. The default (6dB) equates to the inverse distance law for sound propagating in a free field. Lower values may be suitable for simulating more closed environments.
(default: 6)

entry.name: /blur [double]
entry.description:
Sets the blur factor. This should be set in relation to the dimensions of the speaker array. Larger numbers result in more blurring of the spatial image.
(default: 0.001)

entry.name: /max_speakers [int]
entry.description:
Sets the number of speakers that can be non-zero (only the nearest N speakers are used). If this is set to zero then all speakers are used. Reducing the number of speakers used can improve localisation.
(default: 0)

entry.name: /point_factor [double]
entry.description:
Interpolation factor between DBAP (at 0) and point source panning (at 1).
(default: 0)

method.name: info
method.description:
Print info about fl.spatial~ to the max window for reference purposes. If no arguments are provided then all information is posted to the Max window. Else a set of flags is used to select which sections of the reference to display, and whether or not the information should be provided in a shortened form.
The following flags are available:
description - display the object description.inputs - display info on inputs.outputs - display info on outputs.io - display info on both inputs and outputs.parameters - display info on the object parameters.quick - display shorten versions of any info displayed.

attribute.name: rt
attribute.description:
Sets the realtime state for fl.spatial~. When set to 0 fl.spatial~ forms part of a non-realtime network for performing offline processing in Max message threads. This mode of operation uses buffer~ objects for audio IO.
More info on non-realtime processing with FrameLib can be found in Tutorial 11.

attribute.name: id
attribute.description:
Sets the context name for fl.spatial~ in order to determine distinct processing contexts.
More info on FrameLib contexts can be found in Tutorial 10.
